title: 110_hr3513
content: The "Copper Salmon Wilderness Act of 2008" designates the Copper Salmon Wilderness. The Oregon Wilderness Act of 1984 is amended to designate approximately 11,922 acres of land in the Siskiyou National Forest as the Copper Salmon Wilderness. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to file a map and legal description of the wilderness with the Senate and House Committees on Energy and Natural Resources. The Copper Salmon Wilderness, designated under the Oregon Wilderness Act of 1984, encompasses 11,922 acres in the Siskiyou National Forest. The Secretary of Agriculture must file a map and legal description with the Senate and House Committees on Energy and Natural Resources. The filed map and legal description have the same legal force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct typographical errors. If the wilderness boundary shares a border with a road, an offset of up to 150 feet from the road's centerline can be established. The maps and legal descriptions are available for public inspection at Forest Service offices. SEC. 3. WILD AND SCENIC RIVER DESIGNATIONS, ELK RIVER, OREGON. Section 3(a)(76) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to designate specific segments of the North Fork Elk and South Fork Elk rivers in Oregon as scenic or wild rivers. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act designates specific segments of the North Fork Elk and South Fork Elk rivers in Oregon as scenic or wild rivers, including a 4.2-mile segment of the South Fork Elk from Forest Service Road 3353 to its confluence with the North Fork Elk. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF TRIBAL RIGHTS. This Act does not diminish any rights of Indian tribes. The Secretary aims to establish a memorandum of understanding with the Coquille Indian Tribe for access to the Copper Salmon Wilderness for historical and cultural activities. SEC. 5. DESIGNATION OF POTENTIAL WILDERNESS AREA, SISKIYOU NATIONAL FOREST, OREGON. Designation of certain National Forest System land in Oregon as a potential wilderness area for inclusion in the Copper Salmon Wilderness. The Secretary will file a map and legal description of the designated area with the appropriate committees. The map and legal description of the potential wilderness area in Oregon will be available for public inspection. The Secretary will manage the area until it is designated as wilderness. Ecological restoration may involve the use of motorized equipment until wilderness designation, with a focus on minimal impact practices. The Secretary will use minimal tools for ecological restoration in the potential wilderness area, aiming to minimize adverse impacts on wilderness character and resources. The area will be designated as wilderness either when conditions incompatible with the Wilderness Act are removed or 10 years after the enactment of the Act. Once designated, it will be incorporated into the Copper Salmon Wilderness and administered according to relevant laws. The Copper Salmon Wilderness will incorporate the potential wilderness area, with the designation date under subsection (e) replacing the effective date of the Wilderness Act. The Copper Salmon Wilderness incorporating the potential wilderness area was passed by the House of Representatives on April 22, 2008.
